document.title: Learnability and the Statistical Structure of Language: Poverty of Stimulus Arguments Revisited
document.abstract: This paper illustrates this by showing that the "parade case of an innate constraint " (Crain, 1991) i.e., Chomsky's (1975) poverty of stimulus argument that structure dependence must be a principle of UG fails to hold once stochastic information is admitted; the property of language in question is shown to be learnable with a statistical learning algorithm
document.venue: Proceedings of the 26th annual Boston University Conference on Language Development

author.name: John D. Lewis
author.affil: UC San Diego & McGill University, and UC San Diego

author.name: Jeffrey L. Elman
author.affil: UC San Diego & McGill University, and UC San Diego
